verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
verses.comment: Opening formula, standard in Leviticus.

verses.text: If a man has on the skin of his body a swelling, a scab, or a bright spot, and it becomes the plague of leprosy on the skin of his body, then he shall be brought to Aaron the priest or to one of his sons the priests.
verses.comment: “Leprosy” here refers to a range of skin diseases, not just Hansen’s disease.

verses.text: The priest shall examine the sore on the skin of the body. If the hair in the sore has turned white and the sore appears deeper than the skin of his body, it is the plague of leprosy. When the priest has examined him, he shall pronounce him unclean.
verses.comment: Emphasis on priestly diagnosis.

verses.text: But if the bright spot is white on the skin of his body and does not seem deeper than the skin, and its hair has not turned white, the priest shall quarantine the person for seven days.
verses.comment: “Quarantine” used in modern terminology for clarity.

verses.text: The priest shall examine him on the seventh day. If the sore appears the same and has not spread on the skin, the priest shall quarantine him for another seven days.
verses.comment: Repeat quarantine for ambiguous cases.

verses.text: The priest shall examine him again on the seventh day. If the sore has faded and has not spread on the skin, the priest shall pronounce him clean; it was only a scab. He shall wash his clothes and be clean.
verses.comment: Washing as a sign of ritual purity.

verses.text: But if the scab spreads much on the skin after he has been examined by the priest, he shall be presented to the priest again.
verses.comment: Further examination if condition worsens.

verses.text: The priest shall examine him. If the scab has spread on the skin, the priest shall pronounce him unclean. It is leprosy.
verses.comment: "Leprosy" stands for a skin disease making one ritually unclean.

verses.text: When a person has the plague of leprosy, he shall be brought to the priest.
verses.comment: Bringing the diseased person to the priest for examination.

verses.text: The priest shall examine him. If there is a white swelling on the skin, and the hair has turned white, and there is raw flesh in the swelling,
verses.comment: Raw flesh is a sign of serious disease.

verses.text: It is an old leprosy on the skin; the priest shall pronounce him unclean and shall not quarantine him, for he is unclean.
verses.comment: Chronic disease does not require quarantine.

verses.text: If the leprosy breaks out all over the skin and covers all the skin of the diseased person from head to foot wherever the priest can see,
verses.comment: A case where leprosy has spread everywhere.

verses.text: Then the priest shall observe. If the leprosy has covered all his body, he shall pronounce him clean of the disease; it has all turned white. He is clean.
verses.comment: When the disease turns fully white, person is considered clean.

verses.text: But whenever raw flesh appears in him, he shall be unclean.
verses.comment: Raw flesh signals uncleanness again.

verses.text: The priest shall examine the raw flesh and pronounce him unclean; raw flesh is unclean. It is leprosy.
verses.comment: Diagnosis depends on signs visible to priest.

verses.text: If the raw flesh turns again and is changed to white, he shall come to the priest.
verses.comment: Person is reinvestigated if condition improves.

verses.text: The priest shall examine him. If the disease has turned white, the priest shall pronounce the diseased person clean; he is clean.
verses.comment: White skin here means ritual cleanness.

verses.text: When there is a boil on the skin that heals,
verses.comment: New case: a healed boil.

verses.text: And in its place there is a white swelling or a reddish-white spot, then it shall be shown to the priest.
verses.comment: Examination procedure repeats.

verses.text: The priest shall examine it. If it appears deeper than the skin and its hair has turned white, the priest shall pronounce him unclean; it is the plague of leprosy that has broken out in the boil.
verses.comment: Signs same as general leprosy.

verses.text: But if the priest examines it and finds there is no white hair in it and it is not deeper than the skin but has faded, the priest shall quarantine him for seven days.
verses.comment: Ambiguous cases lead to quarantine.

verses.text: If it spreads on the skin, the priest shall pronounce him unclean; it is leprosy.
verses.comment: Spread means uncleanness.

verses.text: But if the bright spot remains in its place and does not spread, it is a scar from the boil; the priest shall pronounce him clean.
verses.comment: A stable spot is not leprosy.

verses.text: Or, when a person has a burn on the skin and the raw area from the burn becomes a reddish-white or white spot,
verses.comment: Case of a burn—is it leprosy?

verses.text: The priest shall examine it. If the hair in the spot has turned white and it appears deeper than the skin, it is leprosy that has broken out in the burn; the priest shall pronounce him unclean.
verses.comment: Same signs determine leprosy.

verses.text: But if the priest examines it and finds there is no white hair in the spot and it is not deeper than the skin but has faded, the priest shall quarantine him for seven days.
verses.comment: Quarantine for unclear cases.

verses.text: The priest shall examine him again on the seventh day. If it has spread on the skin, the priest shall pronounce him unclean; it is leprosy.
verses.comment: Spread indicates leprosy.

verses.text: But if the bright spot stays in its place and has not spread on the skin but has faded, it is a swelling from the burn; the priest shall pronounce him clean, for it is just a scar from the burn.
verses.comment: Translation clarifies scar from burn.

verses.text: If a man or woman has a sore on the head or the beard,
verses.comment: Cases involving scalp or facial hair.

verses.text: The priest shall examine the sore. If it appears deeper than the skin and there is thin yellow hair in it, the priest shall pronounce him unclean; it is a scall, a kind of leprosy of the head or beard.
verses.comment: The Hebrew “netek” rendered as “scall”—a scalp disease.

verses.text: But if the priest examines the sore and finds it does not appear deeper than the skin, and there is no black hair in it, the priest shall quarantine the person with the scall for seven days.
verses.comment: Black hair is a sign of health here.

verses.text: The priest shall examine the sore on the seventh day. If the scall has not spread and there is no yellow hair in it, and the scall does not appear deeper than the skin,
verses.comment: Calculation of scall risk after quarantine.

verses.text: He shall shave himself but not shave the scall, and the priest shall quarantine the person with the scall another seven days.
verses.comment: Shaving is part of diagnosis for clarity.

verses.text: The priest shall examine the scall on the seventh day. If the scall has not spread on the skin and does not appear deeper than the skin, the priest shall pronounce him clean, and he shall wash his clothes and be clean.
verses.comment: Washing clothes indicates return to purity.

verses.text: But if the scall spreads much on the skin after his purification,
verses.comment: Spread indicates new risk.

verses.text: The priest shall examine him. If the scall has spread on the skin, the priest need not look for yellow hair; he is unclean.
verses.comment: Spread overrides other signs.

verses.text: But if the scall remains in place and black hair has grown in it, the scall has healed; he is clean, and the priest shall pronounce him clean.
verses.comment: Black hair shows recovery.

verses.text: If a man or woman has spots on the skin of their body, white spots,
verses.comment: Case of diffuse white spots.

verses.text: The priest shall examine them. If the bright spots on the skin of their body are dull white, it is a harmless skin eruption; they are clean.
verses.comment: ‘Tzara’ath’ not present—this is not leprosy.

verses.text: If a man's hair falls out from his head, he is bald, but he is clean.
verses.comment: Simple baldness is not unclean.

verses.text: If his hair has fallen out from the front part of his head, he is forehead bald, but he is clean.
verses.comment: Pattern baldness clarified.

verses.text: But if there is on the bald head or the bald forehead a reddish-white sore, it is leprosy breaking out in his bald head or his bald forehead.
verses.comment: Red/white sore signals risk.

verses.text: The priest shall examine him. If the swelling of the sore is reddish-white on his bald head or his bald forehead, like the appearance of leprosy on the skin of the body,
verses.comment: Same signs as for other leprosy cases.

verses.text: He is a leprous man; he is unclean. The priest must pronounce him unclean, his disease is on his head.
verses.comment: Unclean status is pronounced by the priest.

verses.text: The leper in whom the disease is present must have his clothes torn and his head uncovered, and he must cover his upper lip and cry out, ‘Unclean, unclean!’
verses.comment: Mourning and warning rituals for leper.

verses.text: He shall remain unclean as long as the disease is in him; he is unclean. He shall live alone; his dwelling shall be outside the camp.
verses.comment: Quarantine outside camp practiced for health and ritual reasons.

verses.text: When there is a spot of leprosy in a garment, whether a woolen or linen garment,
verses.comment: Leprosy here refers to mildew or mold as well.

verses.text: Whether in the warp or the woof of linen or wool, or in leather or anything made of leather,
verses.comment: Warp/woof are weaving terms.

verses.text: If the plague is greenish or reddish in the garment, or in the leather, or in the warp or the woof, or in anything made of leather, it is a plague of leprosy and must be shown to the priest.
verses.comment: Color changes signal uncleanness in material objects.

verses.text: The priest shall examine the plague and quarantine the afflicted thing for seven days.
verses.comment: Objects can be quarantined as well as people.

verses.text: He shall examine the plague on the seventh day. If the plague has spread in the garment, or in the warp or the woof, or in the leather, whatever use the leather is for, the plague is a persistent leprosy; it is unclean.
verses.comment: Spread means persistent uncleanness of materials.

verses.text: He shall burn the garment, the warp or the woof, the wool or linen, or any article of leather in which the plague is; it is a persistent leprosy. It must be burned in fire.
verses.comment: Destruction by fire for persistent uncleanness.

verses.text: But if the priest examines, and the plague has not spread in the garment, the warp or the woof, or in any article of leather,
verses.comment: No spread means possible remediation.

verses.text: Then the priest shall command that they wash what has the plague, and he must quarantine it seven more days.
verses.comment: Washing and additional quarantine for objects.

verses.text: After the plague is washed, the priest shall examine it again. If the plague has not changed its color and has not spread, it is unclean; you shall burn it in fire, no matter if the plague is inside or outside.
verses.comment: Permanent stains require burning.

verses.text: But if the priest examines it and finds the plague has faded after it is washed, he shall tear it out of the garment, the leather, or the warp or the woof.
verses.comment: Removing damaged part to save the rest.

verses.text: If it appears again in the garment, in the warp or the woof, or in any article of leather, it is a spreading plague; you shall burn that with fire, whatever has the plague.
verses.comment: Recurrence means burn all affected.

verses.text: But the garment, the warp or the woof, or any article of leather which you have washed, if the plague has disappeared from it, shall be washed again, and it will be clean.
verses.comment: Valid remediation means ritual cleanness restored.

verses.text: This is the law for the plague of leprosy in a garment of wool or linen, in the warp or the woof, or in any article of leather, to pronounce it clean or unclean.
verses.comment: Summative statement of chapter’s ordinances.
